Hi Jim,

Have you read "On Intellgence" yet by Jeff Hawkins?  He proposes 
several things, including a temporal aspect to how we learn 
everything from any sensory system.  They have done some preliminary 
work on implementing his ideas (of which temorality is one aspect) 
and have had some early good results.  I tend to agree with all his 
basic ideas: brain operates with one algorithm only: brain is 
organized into a hierarchy: time matters in learning: memory is 
critical to learning: and that feedback is critical in the network 
to learning.

I have also partially implemented some of his ideas in a very simple 
visual recognition system..early results are interesting, but I have 
to a do alot more work yet.  it does show some capability for 
invariance, which is pretty cool.

--Kevin



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
<jim_oflaherty_jr@y...> wrote:
> Colin,
> 
> You wrote:
>  > It occured to me that real world neural nets exist in 3D due to 
> physical constr[ai]nts - there are only 3 spa[t]ial dimensions!
> 
> I have not studied the biology of neurons enough to be very 
confident of 
> this speculation.  I think *time* might be another dimension of 
physical 
> neurons.  In other words, there are likely nuances in a physical 
> neuron's firing and the *timing of the receptivity* of a 
> related/connected neuron that had some level of influence on the 
> evolution of the neurons and organ.  And therefore, likely have a 
> reasonable influence on the emergent effects produced.  Which in 
turn 
> effected the further evolution of both the neurons and organ.  A 
strange 
> loop, so to speak.
> 
> As you mention later, the neurons which are modeled in the ANNs we 
have 
> been using in NEAT are very simple compared to physical neurons.  
The 
> idea that *all* the neurons activate in sequence (activation wave) 
> before another activation wave begins is not very similar to 
nature at 
> all.  However, the amount of computing capacity required to 
simulate the 
> highly parallel, massively distributed and mildly chaotic 
(inherent 
> noise) nature of physical neurons means it is much more difficult 
to 
> simulate their behavior than the simple approach currently used.
> 
> Haven't some experiments been done where they added the time 
component 
> to the model and then were able to do some very sophisticated 
learning 
> with very few neurons, compared to the simpler activation wave 
method?
> 
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> Colin Green wrote:
> 
> > Philip Tucker wrote:
> >
> > > [...]
> > >
> > > 2) I'm sure real neural networks have clusters.  It's debatable
> > > whether this is a necessary feature or simply a byproduct of 
biology -
> > > it's much easier for two neurons in close spatial proximity to 
be
> > > connected than those farther apart.  But do neural networks 
have hubs?
> >
> > Not sure but I thought I'd add that the clusters in mammalian 
brains are
> > arranged in columns. The neural column is, I think, the basic 
unit of
> > repetition, and interconnections within a column have been 
observed to
> > be far more numerous than those between columns.
> >
> >
> > > 4) The NEAT paradigm is not biased toward either of these 
network
> > > features.  Any node has an equal chance connecting to any 
other node
> > > (excepting the initial connections between input and output 
nodes).
> >
> > Which would be more like the case /within/ a neural column, for 
example,
> > which contains far more neurons (approx. 100k is a figure I 
recall) than
> > any NEAT evolved ANN I've ever seen. If clustering is a strategy 
for
> > dealing with complexity, and our ANN's don't get very complex 
then it's
> > not clear that it would be a useful strategy to engineer into 
NEAT. On
> > the other hand clustering may happen at numerous levels, so 
e.g.a neural
> > column may contain sub-clusters, some of which may contain very 
small
> > groups similar in size to our ANN's.
> >
> >
> > > Despite this lack of bias in the evolutionary model, do 
clusters or
> > > hubs emerge?  If they are crucial features of an effective 
network,
> > > should we build such biases into the evolutionary process?  For
> > > example, the likelihood of a connection being added between 
two nodes
> > > could be proportional to the connectivity distance between the 
two
> > > (this could be based on a unidirectional or bidirectional 
traversal of
> > > connections).  Or, the weight could be proportional to this 
distance. 
> > > As an alternative to connectivity distance, we could give the 
nodes a
> > > spatial layout, perhaps on a 2-dimensional surface, and have
> > > connection mutation be relative to that spatial distance.
> >
> > As an aside, laying neuron's out in a grid space, 2D, 3D or 
otherwise
> > (why not 4D or more?) is something I've considered when thinking 
about
> > indirect encodings. 'growing' neurons within a limited space is 
one way
> > of preventing an indirect encoding from growing ANN's too large 
to
> > simulate.
> >
> > Actually when I started out doing work on neuro-evolution my 
first
> > instinct was to use grid layouts (I used hexagonal grids) and the
> > question of how many dimensions I should use came up. It occured 
to me
> > that real world neural nets exist in 3D due to physical 
constriants -
> > there are only 3 spacial dimensions! - and this presents a limit 
to the
> > amount of connectivity a biological neural net can achieve, 
because of
> > the physical size of neurons and their connections and the 
limited space
> > available. Therefore it makes sense to connect more to your 
neighbours
> > than to distant neurons.
> >
> > Of course the ANN's in NEAT are effectively dimensionless, any 
neuron
> > can connect to any other without any limits or concept of 
relative
> > distance and the lack of this restriction is one of the benefits 
we have
> > over biology. Perhaps though clustering is not just a strategy 
for
> > dealing with physical limitations, but actually has other 
positive side
> > effects.
> >
> > Trying to engineer some kind of clustering factor into NEAT is an
> > interesting idea. I don;t think it's a substitute for the  
existing
> > modular NEAT approaches because there is no repetition of
> > clusters(unless maybe you can identify them), but it may be a 
more
> > efficient way of evolving small ANN's in general.
> >
> > Colin
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Expanding on the 4D comment above - when I started out with
> >
> >
> >
> > >
> > > - Philip
> > >
> > > --
> > > Philip Tucker
